title: 109_s1560
content: The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Commission on Expanding Social Service Delivery Options Act" and establishes a commission. The Congressional Commission on Expanding Social Service Delivery Options Act establishes a Commission composed of 10 members appointed by various leaders in Congress based on expertise in social service delivery. The Congressional Commission on Expanding Social Service Delivery Options Act establishes a Commission of 10 members appointed by Congress leaders. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled promptly, and co-Chairpersons are designated. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 60 days of enactment. The Commission established by the Act must hold its first meeting promptly. Meetings will be called by either co-Chairperson, and a majority of members constitute a quorum for hearings. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with conducting a study on increasing beneficiary-selected options for social service delivery in Federal programs, including determining areas where beneficiary-directed options can be implemented. The Commission aims to expand consumer choice, maximize governmental resources, and address concerns about faith-based providers in Federal social service programs. They will develop recommendations for implementing beneficiary-selected options in program areas. A report is due within 11 months of enactment. The Commission will submit a report to congressional leaders within 11 months of the Act's enactment, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, the Commission's personnel matters are addressed in Section 5 of the Act. Members of the Commission are compensated based on their status as federal government employees or not. Non-government employees receive daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while government employees serve without additional compensation. All members are entitled to travel expenses at authorized rates. The co-Chairpersons of the Commission have the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. They can also determine their compensation independently. The co-Chairpersons of the Commission have the authority to appoint an executive director and personnel without following civil service laws. The pay rates for personnel cannot exceed the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Commission can procure temporary services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal year 2006 without limitation on availability until expended.
